message_1:
Calculate the change in enthalpy for the following chemical reaction: 

CH4(g) + 2O2(g) -> CO2(g) + 2H2O(l) 

Given that the enthalpies of formation for CH4(g), CO2(g), and H2O(l) are -74.8 kJ/mol, -393.5 kJ/mol, and -285.8 kJ/mol respectively.
message_2:
To calculate the change in enthalpy (ΔH) for the given chemical reaction, we can use the formula:

ΔH = Σ ΔH(products) - Σ ΔH(reactants)

where ΔH(products) is the sum of the enthalpies of formation of the products, and ΔH(reactants) is the sum of the enthalpies of formation of the reactants.

For the given reaction:

CH4(g) + 2O2(g) -> CO2(g) + 2H2O(l)

The enthalpies of formation are:

ΔHf(CH4) = -74.8 kJ/mol
ΔHf(CO2) = -393.5 kJ/mol
ΔHf(H2O) = -285.8 kJ/mol

The enthalpy of formation for O2(g) is 0 kJ/mol since it is in its standard state.

Now, we can calculate the change in enthalpy:

ΔH = [1 × (-393.5) + 2 × (-285.8)] - [1 × (-74.8) + 2 × 0]

ΔH = (-393.5 - 571.6) - (-74.8)

ΔH = -965.1 + 74.8

ΔH = -890.3 kJ/mol

So, the change in enthalpy for the given chemical reaction is -890.3 kJ/mol.
